awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Punctuated versus gradual topographic evolution of Cordilleran-style orogenic belts
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers have long debated how large Cordilleran orogens such as the Sierra Nevada, Cascades and Patagonian Andes develop through time. In particular, two dominant theories have emerged that explain how mountain belts evolve in response to subduction of oceanic crust beneath continental crust. These theories argue for either protracted mountain building, or an episodic model in which topography repeatedly rises and falls due to crustal shortening and removal of lithosphere beneath a subducting arc. The southern Patagonian Andes provides a natural laboratory for evaluating the drivers of long-term topographic change in a classic Cordilleran Orogen. This study aims to quantify the elevation history of the Southern Patagonia Andes for the last 100 million years to test these competing theories for Cordilleran mountain building. Results will improve understanding about how subduction processes shape the Earth's surface and will have broad implications for understanding current and past seismic activity, hazards, and resources. In addition, insight into changes in the ancient environment will shed light on how evolution of large mountain belts influences plants and animals over millions of years. A new Augmented Reality exhibit at the Yale University Peabody Museum will enable countless visitors to virtually explore how mountains influence precipitation and illustrate important concepts in atmospheric processes and geomorphology. Other important societal outcomes include providing support for an early career faculty researcher and broadening participation in an important STEM discipline through graduate and undergraduate recruiting.

There has been a long debate about punctuated versus steady orogeny. In particular, two opposing ideas argue for either protracted orogenesis or an episodic "Cordilleran cycle" in which topography repeatedly rises and falls due to crustal shortening and convective removal of sub-arc lithosphere. The large Cordilleran orogens (e.g. Sierra Nevada, Cascades, Southern Andes) all host massive granitic batholiths that formed from the partial melting of the sub-arc mantle and the migration of silicic melts through the upper crust. This project explores the idea that emplacement of granitic batholiths was the primary driver of topography in the Patagonian Andes and other Cordilleran orogens. The proposed work will reconstruct the Cretaceous to recent stable isotopic composition of paleoprecipitation on the windward and leeward side of the Patagonian Andes to test competing hypotheses for the formation of Cordilleran-style orogens. Volcanic glasses, soil carbonates and sedimentary leaf waxes from several well-dated Cretaceous to recent sedimentary basins will be sampled to reconstruct precipitation deltaD and delta18O. Isotope data will be coupled with a numerical atmospheric physics model with high-resolution water isotope fields to constrain the timing and spatial heterogeneity of topographic change in the Patagonian Andes. The isotope-enabled numerical model deals with observed complexities in the behavior of airflow and produces realistic representation of modern distribution of precipitation isotopes on the scale of an orogen. This approach enables separation of climatic and topographic effects on precipitation isotopes and more accurate reconstructions of topographic change.

por.por_cntn:
Overview
The overall goal of our project was to develop a quantitative basis for the “isotope paleotopography" method and to use this method to measure the Cenozoic evolution of topography for the Patagonian and South Central Andes. 

Specific Contributions
1) The Orographic Precipitation Isotope (OPI) programs are now fully tested and finalized, and are now publicly available on GitHub and Zenodo (Brandon, 2023). The programs provide a process-based representation of the steady stratiform flow of a moist, buoyantly stratified atmosphere over an arbitrary 3D topography. It also includes full numerical calculations for the formation and transport of cloud water and precipitation, and the isotopic fractionation associated with condensation, fallout, and evaporative recycling. The OPI algorithm solves a full forward solution for a 1000 x 1000 km region at a 1 km grid resolution in about 30 s on a high-end laptop. The programs include a direct-search algorithm to estimate the best-fit precipitation climatology from a regional dataset of meteoric water samples. We have also posted the complete datasets and OPI analyses for modern meteoric water samples for our Patagonia and South Central Andes study areas on GitHub and Zenodo (Brandon et al., 2023a, 2023b).

2) Our OPI modeling in modern settings includes not only our Patagonia and South Central Andes study areas (all published, as noted above) but also 6 other settings (Himalaya-Tibet, Taiwan, Ecuador, US Cordillera, Mexican Sierra Madre, and Dominica Island in the Caribbean (publication in progress). This work indicates the following conclusions.

2a) The spatial distributions of precipitation isotopes, as observed on the ground by samples of meteoric water in these study areas, are well fit by the OPI model. Others have argued that high topography will result in blocking (where the air is partially or completely prevented from passing over the topography), or that lifting and isotopic fractionation might be dominated by convective instabilities or by evaporative recycling. The OPI results show these issues have little influence on the time-averaged precipitation isotope field. They also show that isotopic fractionation is linearly related to the maximum lifting along the upwind path, not the local elevation at the sample location. 

2b) Irving Friedman and others demonstrated in the 1980s that hydrated volcanic glass can be used to estimate the hydrogen isotopic composition of meteoric water at the time the glass was deposited. They showed that the glass took about 1 to 10 ka to fully hydrate and that the hydration reaction is irreversible under typical stratigraphic conditions. Nonetheless, many colleagues remain concerned about variably resetting over time. Our results support Friedman's conclusion. As a first example, one of our δ2H glass time series in Patagonia shows a well-defined isotopic excursion that correlates to the inception of the Antarctic ice sheet at 33 Ma (Colwyn and Hren, 2019). As a second example, our South Central Andes study is based on δ2H glass time series, with an average age increment of 0.5 Ma as collected across a single stratigraphic section spanning 55 to 10 Ma. The time series shows events and trends similar to those observed in other global climate records, such as the δ18O benthic foraminifera record of Zachos et al. (2001). If isotopic resetting were common, we would not expect to see these features in our time series. 

3) Our analysis of δ2H glass and paleotopography in the Patagonian Andes was published in Colwyn et al. (2019). The main conclusion is that the Patagonian Andes were formed before 50 Ma, and have maintained a steady height from 50 Ma to present. This result challenges the long-held view that the Patagonian Andes is a young mountain range initiated about 15 Ma ago. This young-Andes interpretation is based on the idea that mountain building is directly correlated to the timing of foreland thrusting. Our view is that tectonic shortening has been continuous over the last 50 Ma and that erosion has kept pace with uplift, resulting in a steady-state topography over that period.

4) Our analysis of δ2H glass and paleotopography in the South Central Andes was published in Fennell et al. (2023). These data also show that the topography of the Andes is older than 55 Ma. We find that the topography was about 25% higher relative to modern topography for the period 55 to 45 Ma, and then was reduced to a steady topography with a height similar to modern for the period 45 to 15 Ma. The period from 15 Ma to present shows a cycle where the topography drops to 50% of its modern height and then rises to its modern height between 10 to 0 Ma. Geodynamic models by others have predicted that temporal changes in plate velocities at the Chile subduction zone would have caused a cycle of subsidence and uplift of both the Andes and the eastern foreland at this time.
